artefact.overview: If your husband, wife or civil partner has died you may be able to get Bereavement  Payment: a one-off, tax-free, lump-sum payment of £2,000

parts.title: Overview
parts.body: If your husband, wife or civil partner has died you may be able to get Bereavement Payment: a one-off, tax-free, lump-sum payment of £2,000.

parts.title: What you'll get
parts.body: You can get a £2,000 payment which is a one-off, tax-free lump sum.

parts.title: Eligibility
parts.body:
You may be able to claim Bereavement Payment if your spouse or civil partner paid National Insurance Contributions (NICs). Contact the National Insurance Contributions Office for more information.

National Insurance Contributions Office
0845 302 1479
Monday to Friday, 8 am to 5 pm

If your spouse or partner’s death was caused by their job, it doesn’t matter if they paid NICs or not

One of the following must also be true:

  • you were under State Pension age when they died
  • your spouse or civil partner was not entitled to Category A state Retirement Pension when they died

If you aren’t sure what Pension they were getting, contact The Pension Service

You can’t get Bereavement Payment if any of the following are true:

  • you were divorced or had dissolved the civil partnership when your spouse or partner died
  • you’re living with another person as husband, wife or civil partner
  • you’re in prison

parts.title: How to claim
parts.body:
You can make a claim over the telephone by contacting the Bereavement Service on 0845 608 8601.

Download a claim form

You can also download a Bereavement Benefits pack (form BB1) from the Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) website.

Download ‘Bereavement Benefits form BB1’ (PDF, 184K)

You can order a Bereavement Benefits pack (form BB1) over the telephone from your nearest Jobcentre Plus office. The pack has help notes on how to complete the claim form.

Contact Jobcentre Plus

Once you’ve completed the form, send it to your nearest Jobcentre Plus office as soon as possible.

Claims can only be backdated 12 months and are dated when the office gets them. If you delay you may lose benefit.

parts.title: Further information
parts.body:
Effect on other benefits

The one-off Bereavement Payment does not generally affect your entitlement to other benefits. But your savings and Bereavement Payment may reduce the amount of means-tested benefits you get like:

  • Income Support
  • income-based Jobseeker’s Allowance
  • Housing Benefit and Council Tax Benefit
  • Employment and Support Allowance

How Bereavement Payment is paid

Bereavement Payments are paid into an account, eg your bank account.
